conclusion: Understand relationship between pressure, volume, and temperature of ideal gas.
Graph shows relationship between pressure and volume at different states.
Use given temperature at state A and properties of gas to find temperature at state D.
Initial state A has pressure of 4 atm and volume of 10 L; final state D has pressure of 2 atm and volume of 40 L.
Use ideal gas law PV = nRT to relate initial and final states.
Set up equation using ideal gas law: 4 x 10 = n x RT and 40 = n x RT.
Substitute known values into equation: 40 = n x 300 x RT.
Solve for n: n = 40 / (300 x RT).
Use same temperature value to find final volume V_D: V_D = (40 / (300 x RT)) x 40.
Calculate final temperature T_D using final volume V_D: T_D = (40 / (300 x V_D)) x 300.
Substitute final volume V_D into equation for T_D: T_D = (40 / (300 x 40)) x 300.
Simplify equation to find T_D: T_D = (40 / 1200) x 300 = 10 K.
Convert temperature from Kelvin to Celsius: T_D = 10 K = 100 C.
The temperature of the gas at state D is 100Â°C.
